Package phonebookApp

Class Coursework

java.lang.Object
phonebookApp.Coursework
public class Coursework extends Object
PhonebookApp, which is a simple Phone Book application and uses many of the techniques we have learned.

It contains two classes: a simple PhoneBook class which stores names and phone numbers and SavedPhoneBook which also stores the information in a file. It also contains a unit test class PhoneBookTest which tests PhoneBook class.

There is also a PhoneBookApp class, which runs as a program (using its run method, or the standard 'main' method, and allows you to save and retrieve phone numbers from a file.

Project features

This code includes the following features which will all gain marks if you use them in your project code:

  • control statements (loops, if etc)
  • using classes, objects and methods
  • inheritance
  • encapsulation and protected variables
  • using collection classes (TreeMap)
  • JUnit tests
  • Javadoc comments and compiled documentation
  • code comments
  • using file IO for persistent storage

What we have not covered

There are a couple of features here which we have not covered in class, but should be easy to use if you want to.

  • TreeMap - the map class we are using is TreeMap instead of HashMap. This is because TreeMap stores its entries in alphabetical order, which is what we want for a phone book. (HashMap stores them in random order.) TreeMap is used just like HashMap, so you can use the HashMap.
  • We use the standalone tag @throws to document IOExceptions which our methods may throw.
    The format is: @throws IOException reason why the exception might be thrown
  • package.html - one of the links at the top of the Javadoc documentation files points to PACKAGE. This file describes the whole program and lists the classes in it. The description comes from a file called package.html in your project folder (with your java files). This is just an HTML file, but can include Javadoc tags etc.
